paper_title: Unveiling the activity origin of ultrathin BiOCl nanosheets for photocatalytic CO2 reduction

catalyst.source: Unveiling the activity origin of ultrathin BiOCl nanosheets for photocatalytic CO2 reduction
catalyst.context: Unveiling the activity origin of ultrathin BiOCl nanosheets for photocatalytic CO2 reduction

catalyst.source: Herein, the dynamic evolutions of surface atomic and electronic structures on ultrathin BiOCl photocatalysts were firstly explored by combining synchronous-illumination X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (SI-XPS) with X-ray diffraction (SI-XRD).
catalyst.context: Ultrathin layered semiconductors have attracted particular attention for various photocatalytic applications, while their surface-structure changes under reaction conditions have been rarely concerned.Herein, the dynamic evolutions of surface atomic and electronic structures on ultrathin BiOCl photocatalysts were firstly explored by combining synchronous-illumination X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (SI-XPS) with X-ray diffraction (SI-XRD).The related results clearly reveal that the exposed 001 facets of ultrathin BiOCl are terminated with chlorine atoms instead of generally considered oxygen atoms.Under steady states, the outward migration of chlorine atoms on BiOCl (001) surfaces resulted in the formation of Bi, Cl, and O atoms with multiple-valence states and length decrease of Cl -O and Bi -O bond within the lattice phase.Under excitation states, the surface chlorine atoms return back to the lattice phase, leading to the elongation of Bi -Cl and Bi -O bonds and the valence-state normalization of Bi, Cl, and O atoms.Owing to these significant atomic-and electronic-structure changes, ultrathin BiOCl nanosheets exhibit the prominent activity enhancement (21.4 mol g -1 h -1 ) for CO 2 reduction to CO compare with bulk BiOCl (3.3 mol g -1 h -1 ).

catalyst.source: Y. Zhang and Y. Bi conceived the idea of BiOCl photocatalyst for CO 2 reduction; Y. Zhang conducted the most of material fabrication and photocatalytic measurement; Z. Xu and W. Hao provided the DFT calculation data.
catalyst.context: In summary, the photo-induced dynamic atomic and electronic structure evolutions in U-BOC catalyst have been firstly verified by SI-XPS and SI-XRD techniques.The related results clearly reveal that the surface exposed Cl atoms would return to the lattice phase under the excited state, leading to the extending of Bi -Cl and Bi -O bonds in interior layers and layer spacing structure in the crystal phase, respectively.Owing to the above structural feature changes, U-BOC exhibits excellent photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity ( 21.36 mol g -1 h -1 ), which is nearly 6.4 times higher than BOC.Thus, this work offers a unique insight into the photo-induced charge transfer, chemical bond and crystal structure evolutions for ultrathin layered materials, which may open a new path for designing semiconductor photocatalysts for highly efficient CO 2 reduction. light source.source: The light source was a 300 W Xe lamp (Microsolar300, PerfectLight).
light source.context: All chemicals were of analytical grade purity, obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., and used as received without further purification.Deionized water (Molecular Corp., 18.25 M cm -2 ) used in the synthesis was from local sources. Ultrathin BiOCl nanosheets were synthesized using a modification of the method proposed by Xiong et al. 43.Specifically, 1 mmol Bi (NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O and 0.400 g of PVP were first dissolved in 25 mL of 0.1 mol L -1 mannitol solution.Then, 5 mL of saturated NaCl solution was added dropwise into the above-mentioned solution.The suspension reacted at 160 C for 3 h.After the hydrothermal reaction, the resulting solid powder was collected, washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times and dried at 60 C for 4 h in air. BiOCl nanosheets were fabricated by a sample chemical deposition method.10 mmol BiCl 3 were added in 200 mL water solution under vigorous stirring in dark condition for 2 h.Then, BiOCl nanosheets were washed with deionized water for several times and dried at 60 C for 4 h. Two-dimension grazing-incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering (2D-GIWAXS) was measured at 13A beamline of the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC, Taiwan).All samples for GI-WAXS were radiated at 12.13 keV X-ray with an incident angle of 0.10-0.15 .The crystalline structure of samples was detected by X-ray diffraction instrument (XRD, X Pert PRO, PANalytical) with Cu K radiation (40 kV) with a scanning rate of 0.067 C s -1 from 10 to 90 .The morphologies of samples were examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, TF20, FEI Tecnai) operated at 200 kV, and atomic force microscope (AFM, Multimode-8, Bruker Nano inc).The electronic structure changes were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250 Xi, ThermoFisher Scientific). 20 mg of photocatalyst powders were dispersed in 50 mL H 2 O.The instrument was initially vacuum-treated and then pumped by 0.1 MPa high-purity CO 2 gas.The reaction temperature was kept around 20 C. The light source was a 300 W Xe lamp (Microsolar300, PerfectLight).The amount of CO and H 2 were determined using a gas chromatograph (GC, 2014 A, Ar carrier, Shimadu).H 2 was detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD).CO was converted to CH 4 by a methanation reactor and then analyzed by the flame ionization detector (FID).The isotope-labeled experiments were performed using 13 CO 2 instead of 12 CO 2 , and the products were analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, 7890A and 5975C, Agilent). To prepare photoelectrodes, the photocatalysts were dispersed in chitosan solution to form a 10 mg mL -1 solution.Then, 0.3 mL of colloidal solution was dip-coated on the pretreated FTO surface and was allowed to dry under vacuum conditions for 24 h at room temperature.Photocurrent measurement was conducted on CHI660D Instruments in a standard three-electrode system with as-prepared BiOCl photoelectrode as the working electrode, Pt foil as the counter electrode, saturated calomel electrode as the reference electrode, and 0.2 mol L -1 Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution as the electrolyte.Before the photocurrent measurement, N 2 or Ar gas was purged into the Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution to remove the dissolved molecular oxygen for 30 min and kept purging during the photocurrent measurement. DFT calculations were conducted by the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) package.The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed to treat the exchange-correlation energy by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional.The projector augmented wave (PAW) was used to depict electron-ion interactions.The plane wave cutoff energy was 350 eV, the energy convergence criterion was set as 10 -4 eV for the self-consistent calculations and the force is calculated until it converged to 0.02 eV/A.A 2 2 5 supercells were used for perfect BOC and U-BOC is constructed as the (001) facets with 15 A vacuum to prevent the interaction between adjacent surfaces.The thickness of our U-BOC model was similar to the as-prepared 4 nm thick BiOCl nanosheets in the experiment.The k-point sampling was restricted to the Gamma point only because of such a large supercell.

reaction medium.source: Their photocatalytic activities for CO 2 reduction using water as an electron donor have been conducted and shown in Fig. 5.
reaction medium.context: Fig. 1a shows the typical transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of the as-obtained BiOCl samples, clearly revealing their welldefined sheet-like structure with an average dimension of 40-50 nm.The high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) image (insert in Fig. 1a) demonstrates a clear lattice fringe with a d-spacing of 0.735 nm, which can be well indexed to the (001) plane of BiOCl crystal structure.Moreover, the HR-TEM images shown in Fig. 1b reveal a lattice fringe with a lattice spacing of 0.275 nm, corresponding to (110) plane.To further explore the thickness, high-resolution atomic force microscopy (AFM) has been performed (Fig. 1c), indicating that the average thickness of these BiOCl nanosheets is 4 nm, corresponding to about five layers.Based on the above results, it can be concluded that the obtained BiOCl sample exhibits the well-defined ultrathin nanosheet structure exposed mainly with 001 facets (marked U-BOC).For comparison, the BiOCl sample with a relatively large thickness was also fabricated.As shown in Fig. S1, except for the increased thickness, the 001 planes with a lattice spacing of 0.275 nm can also be detected in the HR-TEM images (marked BOC).Fig. S2 shows the typical X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for both U-BOC and BOC, and all the diffraction peaks can be indexed to the tetragonal BiOCl structure (JCPDS No: 06-0249).No evident shift for the diffraction peaks of U-BOC can be detected compared with BOC samples, originating from the decrease of crystallization degrees (broadening diffraction peak) due to the ultrathin structure and small size in U-BOC.Based on the above results, the bottom and top surfaces of as-prepared U-BOC and BOC can be identified as 001 facets, while the four side planes are 110 facets (Fig. 1d). To more accurately probe surface crystal structure information, twodimension grazing incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering (2D-GIWAXS) has been employed to study the crystal orientation and layer spacing 44,45.As shown in Figs.2a, b andS3, the U-BOC exhibits more preferred (001) orientation than BOC, which are consistent with the above HR-TEM (Figs. 1b andS1) and XRD (Fig. S2) results.Moreover, the U-BOC exhibits larger layer spacing in out-plane (7.74 A) and in-plane (7.51 A) direction than those of BOC samples (7.52 and 7.29 A), respectively, owing to the slightly changed surface atom arrangement in U-BOC (Tables S1 andS2).To further confirm the above conclusion, X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy was conducted to explore detailed information about the bond length and atom coordination.As shown in Fig. 2c, the Bi L-edge extended XAFS k 2 (k) oscillation curves clearly reveal that the ultrathin structures have less influence on the frequencies but remarkably reduced the amplitude, which should be attributed to the distorted crystal structure.These demonstrations can be further supported by corresponding Fourier transform (FT) of the k 2 (k) functions in R space (Fig. 2d and Table S3). More specifically, the FT curve of BOC exhibits three main peaks at 1.77, 2.78 and 3.73 A, corresponding to Bi-O, Bi-Cl and Bi-Bi coordination, respectively 18,29.Compared with BOC, the Bi -O and Bi -Bi peaks of U-BOC slightly shift to the lower R direction with 0.01 and 0.03 A, respectively, while the Bi -Cl peak position shifts to a higher value (0.09 A), indicating the Bi-O and Bi-Bi bond are slightly shortened as well as the Bi -Cl bond is elongated in the U-BOC.To further explore the surface characteristic, the electron spin resonance (ESR) technique was also employed.As shown in Fig. S4, except for the large noise resulting from the surface-bulk structure transitions, only a weak vacancy signal appears in the U-BOC samples.Furthermore, Raman spectra (Fig. S5) clearly reveal the distinct peak changes of U-BOC with respect to BOC samples, including the intensity decrease, blue shift of vibration peak, and new peak appearances at 74 and 99 cm -1 , corresponding to the first-order scattering Eg and A 1g modes of Bi, respectively.Notably, the decrease of the peak at 198 cm -1 (internal Eg Bi -Cl stretching) should be attributed to the decreased crystallization intensity, while the blue shift and new peak originating from the formation of low-coordinated Bi species in U-BOC 25. The electronic structure characteristics of U-BOC and BOC were explored via density function theory (DFT).As shown in Fig. S6, compared with perfect BOC, the presence of vacuum layer over exposed surface (001) facets of U-BOC results in the significantly enhanced charge density at the surface region, indicating the electron can be easily photoexcited to the conduction band, which can effectively facilitate charge separation and transportation.Notably, the length elongation of Bi-Cl bond in U-BOC surface is also achieved, which is consistent with the results of 2D-GIWAXS and XAFS.Subsequently, steady and timeresolved transient photoluminescence (PL) have also been performed on both U-BOC and BOC to explore the effects of structural characteristics on the photocharge separation and migration capability.As shown in Fig. S7a andb, the PL peaks of BOC and U-BOC can be deconvoluted into three main emission peaks located at 423.8, 460 and 512.7 nm, which are indexed to Cl vacancy, isolated V Bi defects, and triple vacancy associates "V Bi V O V Bi ", respectively 19.Compared with BOC, the significant enhancement of PL peak intensity, especially for triple vacancy associates V Bi ", in U-BOC clearly demonstrates that the increased surface defect states can effectively restrain the charge recombination.The photoluminescence decay kinetics was further investigated by time-resolved spectra (Fig. S7c).The corresponding time-decay curve of as-prepared samples with an emission at 450 nm can well be fitted with a biexponential function (Table S4).More specifically, the U-BOC exhibits longer average lifetimes (13.08 ns) than BOC (9.51 ns), indicating its lower charge recombination under the excited state attributed to the non-radiative defect recombination in the surface 46,47.Based on the above results, the increased photoluminescence intensity and prolonged charge lifetime are apparently associated with surface defect states on the U-BOC.Moreover, ultrafast transient absorption (TA) has been also employed to investigate the excited-state energy relaxation process and charge migration behaviors.As shown in Fig. 2e, the U-BOC exhibits a stimulated emission (SE) signal, which can be characterized by two time constants: 1 2.87 0.08 ps (71.0) and 2 1348.90 141.63 ps (29.0), and the weighted average lifetime is 1341.92 141.43 ps.The photoinduced absorption (PA) signal of BOC shown in Fig. 2f demonstrates two-time constants: 1 4.98 0.13 ps (96.3) and 2 463.77 305 ps (3.7), and the weighted average lifetime is calculated to be 363.59 301 ps.These results indicate that the charge migration ability in BOC is much lower than U-BOC.The (photo)electrochemical performance has been further studied, the linear sweeping voltammograms (LSVs, Fig. S8) and chronoamperometric i-t curves (Fig. S9) clearly reveal that U-BOC exhibits a much higher photocurrent density than BOC, indicating its more efficient charge separation and transfer.To further reveal the interfacial charge transfer process, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed for these obtained samples.According to the Nyquist plots (Fig. S10), the U-BOC exhibits remarkably decreased resistances in charge transport processes compared with BOC.Based on the above results, the ultrathin structure and low-coordinated species in U-BOC can significantly improve the photogenerated charge separation efficiency. To further reveal the effect of low-coordinated species and charge migration behavior in as-prepared samples, synchronous illumination Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (SI-XPS) technique (Fig. S11) was performed to explore the surface chemical state information for water molecules absorption on both U-BOC and BOC 48495051.In the case of U-BOC (Figs. 3a andS12), under the dark condition, the low-coordinated species of O (2x)-, Cl (1x)-and Bi (3x)-have been clearly detected in the low bonding energy (BE) region, indicating the outward migration of surface exposed Cl atoms from the lattice phase due to a relatively weak binding force for the surface exposed Cl atoms.Upon the light irradiation, the typical peaks of low-valence species completely disappear in the SI-XPS spectra, while the reconstructed surface chemical bonds for Bi-O and Bi-Cl bonds are detected again, which is accompanied by significantly enhanced BE offsets for the Bi 4f, O 1s and Cl 2p peaks with 1.04, 1.23 and 1.39 eV, respectively.Moreover, the corresponding contour profiles of U-BOC were obtained under the ground and excitation states have been repeated for four cycles in Fig. 3b, indicating the bond evolution in water molecules absorption on U-BOC has an excellent repeatability.Moreover, the charge migration and surface chemical state on BOC have also been performed by SI-XPS (Fig. S13), and the relatively slight surface bond and structure evolution can be also observed.On the basis of the above SI-XPS results, it can be concluded that the exposed 001 facets of BiOCl nanosheets are terminated with chlorine atoms.Owing to the ultrathin structure and weak binding-force for the surface chlorine atoms, their dynamic migration under the ground and excitation states would lead to the significant evolutions of atomic and electronic structure in the lattice layer.To further confirm the above bond changes of as-prepared samples, synchronous illumination Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (SI-FTIR) was also performed.As shown in Fig. S14a, the Bi-O stretching vibration peak (526 cm -1 ) of U-BOC has been significantly increased under the light irradiation.In contrast, no obvious change on Bi -O stretching vibration peak (526 cm -1 ) can be detected for BOC (Fig. S14b).These SI-FTIR experiments further confirm the above SI-XPS results about the chemical bond variation and charge migration of U-BOC under the photoexcited state. The atomic and electronic structure evolutions from SI-XPS results inspire us to gain deep insight into the crystal structure and energy band structure of BiOCl nanosheets.The novel synchronous illumination Xray diffraction (SI-XRD) technique has been employed to capture the evolution of crystal structure information under light excitation state (Fig. S15) 52.Figs.S16 andS17a show the typical XRD patterns of U-BOC and BOC before and after light irradiation, respectively.It can be clearly seen that under the light irradiation, all the diffraction peaks of both U-BOC and BOC slightly shifted toward the low-value direction, corresponding to the increases of their interlayer lattice spacing ( 4 10 -5 A for U-BOC (Fig. 4a) and 7 10 -5 A for BOC (Fig. S17b), respectively).Combined with the above SI-XPS results, it can be concluded that except for the dynamic evolution of the atomic and electronic structure of BiOCl, the related crystal structure expansions have also been demonstrated.Subsequently, their bandgaps were explored by UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS, inset image of Fig. 4b).As shown in Figs.4b andS18, the bandgap of U-BOC is 3.38 eV, slightly smaller than that of BOC ( 3.56 eV), which might be attributed to the ultrathin structure and surface low-coordinated states.Moreover, the valance band (VB) positions of U-BOC and BOC samples were measured using the valence-band XPS equipped with synchronous photo-irradiation (PVBS).As shown in Fig. 4c, the VB maximum under the ground states for U-BOC and BOC are 1.20 and 3.10 eV (1.90 and 3.80 eV vs. NHE (pH 0)), respectively.Under the light irradiation, the significant shifts of VB position towards the high values changes have been observed on both U-BOC ( 2.20 eV) and BOC ( 3.90 eV) samples, respectively.Based on the above VB values and related bandgaps, the corresponding CB positions under the ground and excitation states have been calculated and shown in Fig. 4d.Obviously, a more negative CB bottom of U-BOC under light excitation has been obtained compared with BOC, indicating that their possibility for CO 2 reduction and water splitting. To further confirm the above results for SI-XPS and SI-XRD, the photocatalytic performances of both U-BOC and BOC samples for CO 2 reduction have been performed.Before CO 2 reduction experiment, the photocatalytic performances for overall water splitting have been first explored.As shown in Fig. S19, a track amount of hydrogen (0.14 mol g -1 h -1 ) is generated over as-prepared U-BOC, while no hydrogen product can be detected in the BOC, which is highly consistent with the bandgap structure variations under excitation states (Fig. 4d).Note that no evident oxygen evolution from water splitting has been detected in both U-BOC and BOC systems.Subsequently, the active species during the overall water splitting process was investigated by an in-situ electron spin resonance (ESR) technique.As shown in Fig. S20, no signal can be observed in the dark condition, indicating that there is no chemisorption of O 2 on the photocatalyst surface.After the UV irradiation for 20 min, the evident ESR sign peak of DMPO/O 2 -can be observed in U-BOC in comparison with that of BOC, indicating that the presence of a huge number of proton and O 2 -active groups in water solution 16.Their photocatalytic activities for CO 2 reduction using water as an electron donor have been conducted and shown in Fig. 5.Note that CO is the dominant product for CO 2 reduction reaction over both U-BOC and BOC photocatalysts, accompanying by a trace amount of CH 4 (Fig. S21), indicating that the preferential two-electron process of CO to the eightelectron reduction of CH 4 .More specifically, U-BOC exhibits much higher photocatalytic activities for CO 2 reduction into CO (64.1 mol g -1 ) than that of BOC samples (10.0 mol g -1 ) during 3 h test (Fig. 5a).Subsequently, the isotopic labeling experiment using 13 CO 2 as the feeding gas (Fig. 5b) was carried out and 13 CO peaks at m/z of 29 were detected in the reaction systems, further confirming that CO should be produced from photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.The photocatalytic stability of U-BOC was also explored by cycling experiments.As shown in Fig. 5c, the U-BOC catalyst can generally keep its original activity ever after three cycles, indicating its excellent photostability for CO 2 reduction.To further reveal the reaction intermediates during the CO 2 reduction process, in situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was employed and the related results are shown in Fig. 5d.Upon light irradiation, the new infrared peaks in the region of 1220-2200 cm -1 gradually increase in intensity for the two samples.The absorption bands at 1249, 1352, 1385, 1481 and 1583 cm -1 in U-BOC and 1231, 1259, 1331, 1380 and 1583 cm -1 in BOC can be attributed to CO 3 2-, originating from the interaction of CO 2 and H 2 O 53.Furthermore, the absorption peaks at 1550 and 1760 cm -1 in U-BOC and 1760, 1550 and 1411 cm -1 in BOC can be assigned to the COOH group, which is regarded as the activation and reaction of adsorbed CO 2 54.More importantly, the most remarkable difference in the in-situ FTIR spectra for the two samples is that the CO absorption peak at 1954 cm -1 can only be detected in the U-BOC system, indicating that abundant CO species is generated on the surface of U-BOC, which are a more important part of an intermediate for the selective generation of CO 55.Subsequently, to further confirm the CO 2 adsorption capacity over these two photocatalysts, CO 2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were carried out 56.As shown in Fig. S22, all the desorption temperatures of CO 2 chemisorption on U-BOC are higher than that of BOC, indicating that absorbed CO 2 molecules are binding with the surface more strongly, due to the surface of U-BOC with strong alkaline active sites caused by the changes of surface atomic and electronic structure.Therefore, these results can be further verified that the above performance for CO 2 reduction on as-prepared catalysts. To further clarify the effect of surface exposed halogen atom on photocatalytic CO 2 reduction, the associated surface substitution (Br or I atoms replacing Cl atoms) experiments were carried out.As shown in Fig. S23, U-BOC exhibits the highest photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity (21.36 mol g -1 h -1 ) than that of Br/U-BOC (17.84 mol g -1 h -1 ) and I/U-BOC (10.38 mol g -1 h -1 ), indicating the electronegativity of the surface exposed halogen atoms can significantly affect the photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction.Herein, it is considered that owing to its higher electronegativity than both Br and I atom, the surface exposed Cl atom in U-BOC can more effectively capture electrons from the lattice phase under the light irradiation, which results in the electron enrichment on the surface Cl atom for enhancing photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity.Thus, based on the above evidence for structure and performance, the catalytic mechanism for clarifying atomic and electronic structure changes over U-BOC in CO 2 reduction process can be summarized as in Scheme 1.For U-BOC catalyst, under the ground state, the surface exposed Cl 1 atom deviates from the lattice phase, the electron injection from Cl 1 to interlayer Bi, O and Cl 2 atoms would result in the appearance of low-coordinated species (Bi (3x)-, O (2x)-and Cl (1x)-) and the bond shortening of Bi -O and Bi -Cl 2 .Under light irradiation, the surface exposed Cl 1 can efficiently attract light energy and fall back to the lattice phase.Simultaneously, the electron injection from low-coordinated species into the surface Cl 1 would induce the length elongation of Bi -O and Bi -Cl 2 bonds, leading to the complete disappearance of low coordinated species and the increase of interlayer spacing.During CO 2 reduction process, CO 2 molecule is initially adsorbed on surface Cl 1 sites of U-BOC, meanwhile, the water molecule is dissociated into hydroxy and hydrogen ions.Then, the active CO 2 molecule interacts with the surface protons, the COOH intermediates are gradually generated.Finally, further protonation process, the CO molecules are progressively yielded on the surface of U-BOC, which can significantly enhance the photocatalytic activity for the CO generation.
